item.title: Java toTitleCase()
item.dc:creator: @Epic_Steve Epic Steve
item.description:
@Epic_Steve wrote:

[quote=“Lothy, post:24, topic:384891”][quote author=Epic Steve link=topic=480656.msg3526128#msg3526128 date=1299828739]

There’s an important distinction to me made though between mine and the other solutions posted. Specifically, some people seem to be forgetting that java’s strings are immutable.
By dealing with the underlying array of primitive characters, I create precisely one string object with each call to the function.
The solutions supplied before mine, which make calls to functions like toLowerCase(), toUppeCase, substring(), and split() are creating countless new string objects.

I was just supplying a solution that was both easy to understand and performs much better.

I have to admit, after running a simple “time taken” test on my solution I then compared it to yours (which of course won) but I didn’t think it would be by that much. :o

StringCapitaliser: Time taken: 1481
TitleCase: Time taken: 34034

Wow…
[/quote]
The reason yours is slower is because you’re creating so many String instances per iteration.

    public String toTitleCase(String words) {
        String str = "";
        for (String s : words.split(" ")) {
            str += Character.toUpperCase(s.charAt(0)) + s.substring(1).toLowerCase() + " ";
        }
        return str;
    }

First line (String str = “” is the first string you create. Next, you create a new string each time you use the +/concat operator. The substring() method returns a new String, which then has toLowerCase() invoked on it returning yet another new String.
For some reason you then tack yet another empty String on the end.

Hopefully that explains the huge disparity in performance for you. For the record, your algorithm would have appeared a bit faster if the test string you used (“p y r o 21 4 lol” or whatever) had fewer spaces, and thus far fewer iterations and String creations.
Obviously you’re better off seeing the worst case though instead of just seeing the best case.[/quote]
Yea, I did use the same string as you (p y r o … etc) and I added the extra " " on the end for the spaces, it removed them, like for example; “Hello World” became “HelloWorld”.

Anyway, thanks for your input… I’ll have to read your code and see how it works, and try and learn from it.

item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

public class StringCapitaliser {

  public static void main(String[] args) {
    String testName = "p y r o 214 lol";
    System.out.println(capitaliseName(testName));
    long start = System.currentTimeMillis();
    for (int i = 0; i < 10000000; i++) {
      capitaliseName(testName);
    }
    long end = System.currentTimeMillis();
    System.out.println("Time taken: " + (end - start));
  }

  public static String capitaliseName(String name) {
    char[] input = name.toCharArray();

    int prevCharVal;
    int charVal = (int) input[0];
    if (charVal >= 97 && charVal <= 122) {
      charVal -= 32;
      input[0] = (char) charVal;
    }

    for (int i = 1; i < input.length; i++) {
      prevCharVal = (int) input[i - 1];
      charVal = (int) input[i];
      if (prevCharVal == 32) { //A space
        if (charVal >= 97 && charVal <= 122) {
          charVal -= 32;
          input[i] = (char) charVal;
        }
      }
      else {
        if (charVal >= 65 && charVal <= 90) {
          charVal += 32;
          input[i] = (char) charVal;
        }
      }
    }
    return new String(input);
  }
}
